summary: Driven to propel science forward and to develop new innovative strategies that can improve osteoporosis patient's quality of life. I use translational science approaches to interrogate large human genetic datasets to identify new drug targets for metabolic bone diseases and validate these in zebrafish and tissue culture model systems.

education.field_of_study: Cilia and Extracellular Matrix and their function in craniofacial cartilage and bone development

school.name: HU University of Applied Sciences Utrecht (Hogeschool Utrecht)

projects.title: Functional studies of Bone Mass genes in the Zebrafish
In silico prioritisation and validation of causal genes that underpin osteoporosis pathogenesis
projects.description: Elizabeth Blackwell Postgraduate Discipline Hopping Fellowship awarded on the bases for me to learn new techniques in population studies. I am using two large genetic cohorts of bone mineral density to find new genes that regulate bone mass. Aim is to use these new genes and work out their functionality in the wet lab. I will use developmental biology and cell biology strategies.

profile_positions.description: Advancing science by stimulating an open, fair, and diverse research environment. Both in the Netherlands and abroad.

profile_positions.description: Foundation Fellowship funded by Versus Arthritis to work on osteoporosis where I will study in silico prioritised genes in zebrafish and tissue culture cells.
profile_positions.title: Research Fellow Versus Arthritis

profile_positions.description: Discipline hopping scheme, currently undertaking a project learning basic bio-informatics and handling big genomic data sets from epidemiology studies. Aim is to identify genes which are involved in the regulation of bone mineral density. This will be done  by developing a prioritisation pipeline, which could be applied on summary data from other population studies as well. This in an international interdisciplinary collaboration between the Bristol Medical School, Translational Health Sciences and  the Translational Research Unit, The University of Queensland Diamantina Institute, Brisbane, Australia.
profile_positions.title: Elizabeth Blackwell Institute Postgraduate Fellow

profile_positions.description: PhD Student in the labs of Professor David Stephens and in collaboration with Dr. Chrissy Hammond.

profile_positions.description: Two rotations, of which the first rotation (~6 months) was for my BSc degree in the lab of Prof. Dr. Stefan Schulte-Merker (daily supervised by Dr. Christina Hammond) working on identifying mutations (TILLING) in bone and cartilage development in the zebrafish. The second rotation (~10 months) was for my MSc. degree in the lab of Prof. Dr. Edwin Cuppen, supervised by Dr. Ruben van Boxtel (Hubrecht Institute, Utrecht, NL) where I studied G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) mutants (generated by ENU) in the rat.
profile_positions.title: Master Degree Student
